title: LA R users group: LA R Users: Mar Meeting 2021  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
LA R Users Group will have our March meeting online on Zoom (https://usc.zoom.us/j/92828963940).

**Talk 1**

In this talk, attendees will get an introduction to writing command-line interfaces in R. The talk begins with a discussion of fundamental command-line topics like managing output streams, exit codes, and environment variables. After that, the talk will explain each argument to the "Rscript" executable. The talk will then describe how to write your own R programs that take in command-line arguments, using builtin functions like `commandArgs()` and external packages like {argparse} and {crayon}. The talk concludes with a demo of two R command-line interfaces used in the {lightgbm} project: one for running linting with {lintr} in continuous integration and one for building a C++ library using CMake. Sample code will be available on GitHub prior to and following the talk.

**Speaker**: James Lamb

James Lamb is an engineer at Saturn Cloud, where he works on a team building a managed Dask + Kubernetes product. He is a maintainer on {lightgbm}, and has made many contributions to other open source data science projects, including {xgboost} and prefect. He is also a maintainer and co-author of two other packages on CRAN: {pkgnet} and {uptasticsearch}. He holds masters degrees in Applied Economics (2014) and Data Science (2018). Before joining Saturn, he worked as an IoT Data Scientist at Amazon Web Services and Uptake.

**Talk 2**

While working remotely, I often have client projects where RStudio is unavailable for data security reasons or otherwise. R is feature-rich environment for terminal users as well, and I will discuss the underappreciated
functions around highlighting, graphics, editor integration, and other nice-to-haves for day-to-day
usage of the terminal.

**Speaker**: Neal Fultz

Neal Fultz is a long-time friend of the LA RUG/Tech community. Check out his Github https://github.com/nfultz or his past talks at https://nfultz.github.io/talks

**Schedule**
6:20 Open Zoom
6:25 Breakout room social
6:30 James
7:00 Neal
7:20~8:00 Q&A and social (Combined)

**Code of Conduct**: https://github.com/laRusers/codeofconduct

**LA R Users Group**
Invite yourself to our Slack group: https://socalrug.herokuapp.com/
Ask us any questions by email: [masked]
Find our previous talks on GitHub: https://github.com/laRusers/presentations
Follow us on Twitter: @la_Rusers
Check out more events: https://socalr.org/

***** DON'T BE SHY *******
Reach out if you want to be our speaker. First-time speakers are welcome

title: LA R users group: [OCRUG X-Post] Virtual Data Science Hackathon - **Signup on Eventbrite  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Cross-post for OCRUG:
***REGISTER ON EVENTBRITE***
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ocrug-virtual-data-science-hackathon-tickets-144355327671

******************************************************************

We are excited to announce that the second Orange Country R Users Group (OCRUG) data science hackathon now has tickets available. It is a weekend-long event.

During this event, we will be exploring an interesting data set, starting from the raw data all the way through to a final "end product" (e.g. a data visualization, an interesting data insight, a predictive model, etc.).

This event is open to all experience levels, from the complete beginner to the highly experienced. Participants will work in teams to "hack" through the data and will present their work at the end of the event for prizes. You are free to create your own team, or we will assist in team creation if you do not have one. This is a great way to network, share, and learn from others.

The main goal of the hackathon is to promote teamwork and foster education and learning in a welcoming environment. Though teams will be competing to present their best work at the end of the event for prizes, communication and providing assistance across teams is highly encouraged. We will provide in-person training during the hackathon and online training prior to the event.

We have set up a GitHub repository that has more information about the hackathon. Such as the schedule; setting up slack and much more. Further information will be provided prior to the event.

All participants must abide by the OCRUG Code of Conduct and R Consortium Code of Conduct.

This will be an online event.

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Book club  - Text Mining with R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Are you looking to improve our R skills? Come just us for a book club. It will be headed up by John Peach. The idea is to motivate us to read books and discussing them together. This will help all of us to develop our skills.

The format will be that the leader will prepare a short summary of the material and present it to the group. We will then discuss the material and do some exercises.

The expectations are that you will attend regularly. If you cannot make a commitment to attend, please wait until the next book club starts. It is also expected that participants will take turns being the leader. The leader should prepare a summary of the material that was read and present it to the group.

We will meet each week, Monday evening between 6:30 and 8:00 PM for six weeks.

Book: Title: Text Mining with R
Online: https://www.tidytextmining.com/
Dead Tree: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1491981652/

Signing up: When you sign-up you will be placed on the waiting list. We always have a lot of interest but the book club is a significant commitment. The coordinator will confirm your commitment. Please make sure that you get meet-up emails.

Session 1:
* C1: The Tidy Text Format
* C2: Sentiment Analysis with Tidy Data
* Exercise

Session 2:
* C3: Analyzing Word and Document Frequency: tf-idf
* C4: Relationships Between Words: N-grams and Correlations
* Exercise

Session 3:
* C5: Converting to and from Nontidy Formats
* C6: Topic Modeling

Session 4:
* C7: Case Study: Comparing Twitter Archives
* Exercise

Session 5:
* C8: Case Study: Mining NASA Metadata
* Exercise

Session 6:
* C9: Case Study: Analyzing Usenet Text
* Exercise

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R): Evan Odell - Analysing Political Speeches in R - some approaches  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe
group: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R)
description:
stream: https://youtu.be/HYkwW1e18lU
speaker: Evan Odell https://evanodell.com/
title: Analysing Political Speeches in R - some approaches

speaker's affiliations:
- Junior Data Consultant at Pandata GmbH
- Create and maintainer of the dataset of speeches made in the UK House of Commons

- webinars http://whyr.pl/webinars/
- subscribe http://whyr.pl/subscribe/
- slack http://whyr.pl/slack/
- meetup http://tiny.cc/WarsawRUG

Abstract:
Junior data consultant at Pandata and R programmer, based in Berlin. Evan has written numerous R packages, primarily for accessing and processing data, and created a dataset of UK House of Commons speeches available as a single RDS or CSV file. He has previously worked for Disability Rights UK, Queen'sUniversity and as a freelancer for London Business School.

Short Bio:
Legislative debate transcripts can provide unique insights into politics and policy. They can be used to identify popular topics among different legislators, reveal party factions that do not show up in voting behaviour, and longitudinal
changes in the language used to discuss certain topics, amongst other things. In this webinar I'll discuss some approaches
and potential pitfalls to analysing legislative debate, using the British House of Commons as an example.

# Sponsors #JumpingRivers

The event is kindly sponsored by Jumping Rivers.

Jumping Rivers is an analytics company whose passion is data and machine learning.

https://www.jumpingrivers.com/
twitter: twitter.com/jumping_uk
linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/jumping-rivers-ltd/

title: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R): X-Europe Webinar #17 - Apache Arrow & Flight on Data Lakes  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe
group: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R)
description:
MEETUP DESCRIPTION

In an effort to be data driven, many organizations are looking to democratize data. However, they often struggle with increasingly larger data volumes, reverting back to bottlenecking data access to manage large numbers of data engineering requests and rising data warehousing costs. To address this, a next-gen cloud data lake architecture has emerged that brings together the best attributes of the data warehouse and the data lake. This new open data architecture is built to maximize data access with minimal data movement and no data copies.

- How “no data copy” approach dramatically streamlines data workflows while reducing security and governance overhead
- Why agile development concepts, when applied to the data tier, can dramatically increase data engineering agility
- How to separate compute and data by preserving data in open file and table formats
- How a next-generation cloud data lake architecture brings together the best attributes of data warehouse and data lakes to truly democratize data

### REGISTRATION INFO

-->>> Registration link: https://apache-arrow-datalake.carrd.co/ <<<--
Please also RSVP here on the Meetup Page.

### Our Speaker

Viktor Kessler
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/viktor-kessler/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/ViktorKessler

Viktor Kessler is Senior Solutions Architect at Dremio and a ex-MongoDB Senior Solutions Architect.

### ABOUT THE X-EUROPE DATA SCIENCE WEBINARS

X-Europe Webinar Series is a joint online event of Vienna Data Science Group, Frankfurt Data Science, Budapest Data Science Meetup, BCN Analytics, Budapest.AI, Barcelona Data Science and Machine Learning Meetup, Budapest Deep Learning Reading Seminar, Warsaw R Users Group, PyData Slovakia, and Data Scientists Ireland.

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): Cross-Post / Making the shift from excel to R: perspectives from the back-office  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
Making the shift from excel to R: perspectives from the back-office
Presentation by Mandip Mistry

Abstract:
The back-office of financial institutions is the glue that keeps it all together. This type of work often involves trade processing, trade confirmation, and settlement of payments. In many institutions, much of this work is done manually using excel spreadsheets. This presentation will focus on how someone in the back-office can use R to automate manual processes and how they might convince others on their team to join the journey.

Bio:
Mandip Mistry is a Business Analyst at the Health Care of Ontario Pension Plan. In his role, he is responsible for enhancements and ongoing support of HOOPP's internal stress testing system which provides risk reporting to a variety of stakeholders within the organization. Before this, he spent 5 years in Investment Operations (aka back-office) helping automate manual excel processes while developing a healthy obsession for all things R. Mandip is also a certified tidyverse instructor currently working with back and middle office staff who have fallen out of love with Excel.

This is a cross-post from the group here: https://www.meetup.com/RStudio-Enterprise-Community-Meetup

You can RSVP here on the Boston group though and don't have to join the group above, well unless you want to :)

title: Inland Northwest R User Group (INRUG): Using R to analyze and model COVID-19 cases  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Speaker: Dr. Krisztian Magori

Title: Using R to analyze and model COVID-19 cases

Abstract: Many years from now, we will all think back to what we were doing during the COVID-19 pandemic, and how we contributed to resolving it. In my presentation, I will show you three small projects I conducted related to the pandemic, and look for your feedback. First, I analyzed COVID-19 case trends across the State of Washington, particularly in Spokane, in order for myself to see behind daily case counts, and still looking for ways to expand that. Second, I tested the oft-heard suggestion that increased case numbers in the fall of 2020 were simply due to increased testing, using bootstrapping methods. Finally, I developed a stochastic, spatially explicit model to simulate COVID-19 transmission within a facility, such as a dorm, with visualization conducted in R.

Speaker Profile: Krisztian Magori,Ph.D., is a Associate Professor of Biostatistics at the Department of Biology at Eastern Washington University. He teaches biostatistics using R at both the undergraduate and graduate level, and consults with faculty and students on statistical analysis of their datasets. In addition, he is a disease ecologist, focusing on ticks and mosquitoes, when we don't have a pandemic that's more important.

title: Cleveland R User Group: Alison Hill: Making R Markdown work better for you  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Made with yarn, strings, and glue: Making R Markdown work better for you

Alison Hill is a data scientist, behavioral scientist, and an award-winning educator. At RStudio, Dr. Hill works to expand how data scientists can communicate when they use RStudio’s tools for collaborating, sharing, and presenting. Alison loves teaching, and has led advanced workshops on data science communication and machine learning at rstudio::conf, R / Medicine, and R in Pharma. She is also an international keynote speaker (https://alison.rbind.io/talks), co-developer of the palmerpenguins (https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/) and distill (https://rstudio.github.io/distill/) R packages, and co-author of the book blogdown: Creating Websites with R Markdown (https://bookdown.org/yihui/blogdown/).

Note: this talk will be recorded and posted on our YouTube channel.

title: AalborgRUG: Graphical models with sparse conditional probability tables in R  [Virtual] , Denmark, Europe
description:
Password to the zoom meeting: aalborgrug

The talk will include

- A brief introduction to graphical models
- Discussion of R packages dealing with graphical models
- Sparse conditional probability tables
- A novel method for handling inference via JTA in massive networks

Graphical models is a family of probability distributions that can be interpreted using directed or undirected graphs in which each node represents a random variable; an edge between two variables indicates a relationship between these. Such a graphical representation is convenient, since, for high-dimensional problems the local interpretation of a subset of variables can be interpreted in the sub-graph induced by these variables and variables connected to these. By exploiting the graph-theoretic representation, general algorithms can be used for computing marginal and conditional probabilities. For problems large enough, it can be impossible to compute such probabilities without exploiting the graphical representation. Of particular importance for calculations of probabilities in graphical models is the Junction Tree Algorithm (JTA).

title: AalborgRUG: Online event by [useR! Oslo]: Get Your Results Faster With {future}  [Virtual] , Denmark, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

Host link: https://www.meetup.com/Oslo-useR-Group/events/277150580

[Abstract]
The {future} package offers a unifying framework to distributed computing in R. It lets you run exactly the same code – and achieve exactly the same results – sequentially on your laptop, in parallel on your laptop, in the cloud, or on large computing clusters. In this talk, Øystein will highlight various ways {future} lets you do your data science tasks more efficiently, from file system operations and preparation of large datasets to statistics and machine learning tasks like cross-validation, bootstrapping, and simulations. He'll focus particularly on functional programming with {future.apply} and {furrr} in parallel on a decent laptop, but will also touch upon cloud and cluster computing and package development.

[Bio]
Øystein Sørensen is an Associate Professor in Statistics at the Department of Psychology, University of Oslo (UiO). He works on both applied data analysis projects within cognitive neuroscience as well as development of new statistical tools, typically involving generalized additive models, and he is the author of four R packages. He received his PhD from the UiO in 2014, after which he worked as a data scientist in Storebrand and NextBridge analytics prior to joining UiO in 2018. His homepage is https://osorensen.rbind.io/.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Stacked Ensemble Modeling with Tidy Data Principles  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our April Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event, and the passcode is[masked].

Stacked ensemble modeling is a statistical modeling technique that involves training a model to combine the outputs of many constituent models. The technique has been shown to increase predictive performance in a variety of settings. This talk will introduce {stacks}, a free and open-source R software package for stacked ensemble modeling that aligns with tidy data principles. The package’s functionality is closely aligned with the {tidymodels}, a collection of packages providing a unified interface to diverse statistical modeling techniques.

Simon Couch is a developer on open source R packages for statistical modeling. He is currently an undergraduate studying statistics at Reed College and formerly an intern at RStudio. Simon was awarded the 2021 John M. Chambers Statistical Software Award for {stacks}.

description:
Hello everyone. Thanks to everyone who attended the February meeting, where Rob Gordon discussed HTML scraping, and John Hackett provided an overview of ODBC with R. Our next meeting will be on March 25th, where we plan to have two presentations of 20 - 30 minutes each.

Speakers for March:
- "Reproducibility with the Rmarkdown/Knitr Ecosystem", by Melinda Higgins, Research Professor at Emory's Office of Nursing Research
- "Debugging an R Program - Monte Carlo Simulations of Bernoulli Trials" by Leonard Greski, principal consultant at Leading Agile

Content from past meetings is available at https://atl-r-users.github.io/communications/

Speaker Bios:

Melinda Higgins is co-founder of R-Ladies Atlanta, https://www.meetup.com/rladies-atlanta/ and current [masked]) Vice Chair of District 5 for the American Statistical Association Council of Chapters, https://www.amstat.org/ASA/Membership/Chapters.aspx . She is also the author/creator of two online courses: R for SAS Users, https://www.datacamp.com/courses/r-for-sas-users, and Reproducible Templates for Analysis and Dissemination, https://www.coursera.org/learn/reproducible-templates-analysis . She is a senior biostatistician and research professor in the Office of Nursing Research - School of Nursing - Emory University in Atlanta, GA (2007-current), https://www.nursing.emory.edu/faculty-staff/melinda-k-higgins . She is the author and teacher of two PhD level courses at Emory: Quantitative Analysis of Clinical Data, https://melindahiggins2000.github.io/N736/ every Fall semester and Big Data Analytics for Healthcare, https://melindahiggins2000.github.io/N741bigdata/ every Spring semester. Prior to that she was a Principal Research Scientist at the Georgia Tech Research Institute [masked]), https://gtri.gatech.edu/ and Program Manager for the $17M National Guard Bureau Technology Consortium.

She has over 25+ years experience performing and managing research in wide-ranging applications including healthcare bio-behavioral phenotype characterization and modeling, statistical support for clinical trials, aircraft sensor systems, remote sensing, multispectral/hyperspectral processing, signatures intelligence, knowledge decision support systems, geospatial information systems, sensors and image fusion, and target recognition.

Dr. Higgins has two graduate degrees – a Masters in Statistics and a PhD in Chemometrics/Analytical Chemistry – both from University of South Carolina.

Abstract: Legislative debate transcripts can provide unique insights into politics and policy. They can be used to identify popular topics among different legislators, reveal party factions that do not show up in voting behaviour, and longitudinal changes in the language used to discuss certain topics, amongst other things. In this webinar I'll discuss some approaches and potential pitfalls to analysing legislative debate, using the British House of Commons as an example.

Biography: Evan Odell is a junior data consultant at Pandata and R programmer, based in Berlin. Evan has written numerous R packages, primarily for accessing and processing data, and created a dataset of UK House of Commons speeches available as a single RDS or CSV file. He has previously worked for Disability Rights UK, Queen's University and as a freelancer for London Business School.

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by LA R Users - R in Command Line  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

Please note - Time of event is early morning because event is hosted at Pacific Daylight Time.
https://www.meetup.com/Los-Angeles-R-Users-Group-Data-Science/events/276724295/

**Talk 1**

In this talk, attendees will get an introduction to writing command-line interfaces in R. The talk begins with a discussion of fundamental command-line topics like managing output streams, exit codes, and environment variables. After that, the talk will explain each argument to the "Rscript" executable. The talk will then describe how to write your own R programs that take in command-line arguments, using builtin functions like `commandArgs()` and external packages like {argparse} and {crayon}. The talk concludes with a demo of two R command-line interfaces used in the {lightgbm} project: one for running linting with {lintr} in continuous integration and one for building a C++ library using CMake. Sample code will be available on GitHub prior to and following the talk.

**Speaker**: James Lamb

James Lamb is an engineer at Saturn Cloud, where he works on a team building a managed Dask + Kubernetes product. He is a maintainer on {lightgbm}, and has made many contributions to other open source data science projects, including {xgboost} and prefect. He is also a maintainer and co-author of two other packages on CRAN: {pkgnet} and {uptasticsearch}. He holds masters degrees in Applied Economics (2014) and Data Science (2018). Before joining Saturn, he worked as an IoT Data Scientist at Amazon Web Services and Uptake.

**Talk 2**

While working remotely, I often have client projects where RStudio is unavailable for data security reasons or otherwise. R is feature-rich environment for terminal users as well, and I will discuss the underappreciated
functions around highlighting, graphics, editor integration, and other nice-to-haves for day-to-day
usage of the terminal.

**Speaker**: Neal Fultz

Neal Fultz is a long-time friend of the LA RUG/Tech community. Check out his Github https://github.com/nfultz or his past talks at https://nfultz.github.io/talks

**Schedule**
6:20 Open Zoom
6:25 Breakout room social
6:30 James
7:00 Neal
7:20~8:00 Q&A and social (Combined)

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by Brighton R - Shiny in production with {golem}  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

BrightonR is back for the first virtual meetup of 2021!

Please sign up for the event on our EventBrite page: https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/brighton-r-april-meetup-tickets-146323695111

We're delighted to host Chris Beeley, Senior Data Scientist at Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust, who will speak about the working practices that have evolved at Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust that are focused on allowing a group of data scientists to collaborate on Shiny applications, ensuring that the code that they write is robust, error free, and easily deployable. Shiny applications are produced according to best practice as defined by the {golem} package, and the modularity inherent in that approach is key to making the applications robust as well as allowing the git and GitHub based collaboration to work effectively.

A number of examples of modular and {golem} based development will be discussed, including some of technical hurdles and challenges faced by developers who are beginning to use Shiny modules, and some of the advanced features of Shiny and {golem} that can make building robust and scalable applications easier

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by R Ladies Tunis  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

Title: A Tidy Transcriptomics introduction to bulk and scRNA sequencing analyses

In order to attend the event, please fill out this form 👉 https://tinyurl.com/y88sxkos
- Please register by Friday, April 9,[masked]:00 AM

We are delighted to get back to the R4Bioinfo series that we've launched in September 2020. We will be organizing a new workshop which will serve as a Tidy Transcriptomics introduction to bulk and scRNA sequencing analyses.

Date/Time: Saturday, April 9, 2021 from 10 AM to 12:15 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom https://zoom.us/download

▶️ Invited trainers: Dr. Stefano Mangiola and Dr. Maria Doyle

▶️ About Dr. Stefano Mangiola:
Dr. Stefano Mangiola is currently a Postdoctoral researcher in the laboratory of Prof. Tony Papenfuss. His background spans from biotechnology to bioinformatics and biostatistics. His research focuses on prostate and breast tumour microenvironment, the development of statistical model for the analysis of RNA sequencing data, and data analysis and visualisation interfaces.

▶️ About Dr. Maria Doyle:
Dr. Maria Doyle is the Application and Training Specialist for Research Computing at the Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre in Melbourne, Australia. She has a PhD in Molecular Biology and currently works in bioinformatics and data science education and training. She is passionate about supporting researchers, reproducible research, open source and tidy data.

▶️ About the workshop:

This workshop will present how to perform analysis of RNA sequencing data following the tidy data paradigm (Wickham and others 2014). The tidy data paradigm provides a standard way to organise data values within a dataset, where each variable is a column, each observation is a row, and data is manipulated using an easy-to-understand vocabulary. Most importantly, the data structure remains consistent across manipulation and analysis functions.
This can be achieved for RNA sequencing data with the tidybulk, tidyHeatmap (Mangiola and Papenfuss 2020) and tidyverse (Wickham et al. 2019) packages. The tidybulk package provides a tidy data structure and a modular framework for bulk transcriptional analyses. tidyHeatmap provides a tidy implementation of ComplexHeatmap. These packages are part of the tidytranscriptomics suite that introduces a tidy approach to RNA sequencing data representation and analysis. The last section of the workshop will be focused on the analysis of single cell data in a tidy fashion with the packages tidySCE and tidyseurat.

The topics presented in this workshop will be:

▪️ Data exploration
▪️ Data dimensionality reduction and clustering
▪️ Differential gene expression analysis
▪️ Data visualisation

In order to attend the event, please fill out this form 👉 https://tinyurl.com/y88sxkos

We will send you the Zoom link and the enter passcode a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

Don't forget to add the meetup to your calendar so that you get a reminder about it.

We look forward to welcoming you!

If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to contact us ⬇️

▪️ Email : [masked]
▪️ LinkedIn : https://tinyurl.com/y8hlt5np
▪️ Meetup : https://www.meetup.com/rladies-tunis/
▪️ Twitter : https://twitter.com/RLadiesTunis
▪️ Instagram : https://www.instagram.com/rladiestunis/

In this talk, Cédric presents his favorite tips and tricks with regard to the {ggplot2} package, covering {ggplot2} functionality to improve the design of your graph as well as a collection of interesting extension packages. He is going to cover a diverse collection of tips so hopefully everyone, no matter if beginner or an experienced {ggplot2} user, will learn something helpful!

After the presentation, there will be a live-coding part where you can follow along Cédric in creating an beautiful graph. To follow along, please have the following packages installed:

install.packages(c("tidyverse", "systemfonts", "scico", "ggtext", "ggforce", "ggdist", "magick", "patchwork"))

Note: This is an extended version of the {ggplot2} talk that Cédric gave recently at the Outlier Conference.

[Bio]
Cédric is a computational ecologist by training and a data visualization designer by heart with more than 10 years of hypothesis-driven research experience. For all his projects, no matter if scientific, client or personal projects, he uses {ggplot2} to create powerful and aesthetically pleasing visualizations.

[About]
This event is organized by the Oslo useR! Group (https://www.meetup.com/Oslo-useR-Group/) and will be co-hosted by the Skåne useR! Group (https://www.meetup.com/Skane-R-User-Group/).

description:
[Abstract]
In this talk, I (Mickaël Canouil, https://m.canouil.fr) will chronicle my journey towards a more transparent and reproducible work environment. I will talk about the changes and improvements that I have implemented in my team, detailing the transition of infrastructure used when I arrived to an infrastructure using Docker and the {renv} R package.

[Bio]
I am a biostatistician (Ph.D.) and the head of a small team within a research laboratory, working primarily on the genetics of diabetes and obesity.
I have developed a few R packages, and although some are not very useful, they are most definitely entertaining (i.e., https://github.com/mcanouil/ggpacman/).
I also enjoy watching movies and playing with R (https://m.canouil.fr/imdb_ratings/).

title: Vienna<-R: L.A. R Users / ViennaR: R from the Command line  [Virtual] , Austria, Europe
description:
Going GLOBAL big time - warning - heavy toll on the time-diff, so keep your strong coffee at hand and what the heck :-)

https://www.meetup.com/Los-Angeles-R-Users-Group-Data-Science/events/276724295/

LA R Users Group will have their March meeting online on Zoom (https://usc.zoom.us/j/92828963940).

**Talk 1**

In this talk, attendees will get an introduction to writing command-line interfaces in R. The talk begins with a discussion of fundamental command-line topics like managing output streams, exit codes, and environment variables. After that, the talk will explain each argument to the "Rscript" executable. The talk will then describe how to write your own R programs that take in command-line arguments, using builtin functions like `commandArgs()` and external packages like {argparse} and {crayon}. The talk concludes with a demo of two R command-line interfaces used in the {lightgbm} project: one for running linting with {lintr} in continuous integration and one for building a C++ library using CMake. Sample code will be available on GitHub prior to and following the talk.

**Speaker**: James Lamb

James Lamb is an engineer at Saturn Cloud, where he works on a team building a managed Dask + Kubernetes product. He is a maintainer on {lightgbm}, and has made many contributions to other open source data science projects, including {xgboost} and prefect. He is also a maintainer and co-author of two other packages on CRAN: {pkgnet} and {uptasticsearch}. He holds masters degrees in Applied Economics (2014) and Data Science (2018). Before joining Saturn, he worked as an IoT Data Scientist at Amazon Web Services and Uptake.

**Talk 2**

While working remotely, I often have client projects where RStudio is unavailable for data security reasons or otherwise. R is feature-rich environment for terminal users as well, and I will discuss the underappreciated
functions around highlighting, graphics, editor integration, and other nice-to-haves for day-to-day
usage of the terminal.

**Speaker**: Neal Fultz

Neal Fultz is a long-time friend of the LA RUG/Tech community. Check out his Github https://github.com/nfultz or his past talks at https://nfultz.github.io/talks

**Schedule**
times in Los Angeles TZ:
6:20 Open Zoom [~02: 20 CET]
6:25 Breakout room social
6:30 James
7:00 Neal
7:20~8:00 Q&A and social (Combined) [~04:00 CET]

title: Vienna<-R: Aalborg RUG / ViennaR: Graphical models w sparse cond. prob. tables in R  [Virtual] , Austria, Europe
description:
Password to this zoom meeting: aalborgrug

The talk will include

- A brief introduction to graphical models
- Discussion of R packages dealing with graphical models
- Sparse conditional probability tables
- A novel method for handling inference via JTA in massive networks

Graphical models is a family of probability distributions that can be interpreted using directed or undirected graphs in which each node represents a random variable; an edge between two variables indicates a relationship between these. Such a graphical representation is convenient, since, for high-dimensional problems the local interpretation of a subset of variables can be interpreted in the sub-graph induced by these variables and variables connected to these. By exploiting the graph-theoretic representation, general algorithms can be used for computing marginal and conditional probabilities. For problems large enough, it can be impossible to compute such probabilities without exploiting the graphical representation. Of particular importance for calculations of probabilities in graphical models is the Junction Tree Algorithm (JTA).

title: Vienna<-R: BrightonR / ViennaR - April Meetup [w a focus on {golem} Shiny applications]  [Virtual] , Austria, Europe
description:
BrightonR this time hosts Chris Beeley, Senior Data Scientist at Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust, who will speak about the working practices that have evolved at Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust that are focused on allowing a group of data scientists to collaborate on Shiny applications, ensuring that the code that they write is robust, error free, and easily deployable.
Shiny applications are produced according to best practice as defined by the {golem} package, and the modularity inherent in that approach is key to making the applications robust as well as allowing the git and GitHub based collaboration to work effectively.

A number of examples of modular and {golem} based development will be discussed, including some of technical hurdles and challenges faced by developers who are beginning to use Shiny modules, and some of the advanced features of Shiny and {golem} that can make building robust and scalable applications easier.

Pls sign up at EventBrite:
https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/brighton-r-april-meetup-tickets-146323695111

description:
Details
“Develop an R package”, they said… What does this even mean?

In this session with a live demo, we shall demystify the creation of an R package. R packages are mostly well-organized folders, and there are automatic tools to help. Let’s dive into the wonders of usethis! We shall also see why to create a package (or not). We shall furthermore explain how to improve your R package and your own package development skills. And how to solve the specific new challenges you will encounter! Last but not least we will discuss how to find your happy place in the world of R package development.

Do you want to be more of a devoted maintainer of one single package? Or perhaps a valued contributor to dozens of packages?

==================
About the Speaker
==================
Maelle Salmon is a R(esearch) Software Engineer & Blogger based in Nancy, France. She is also the associate editor for rOpenSci’s Software Peer Review (peer-review system of R packages), and the main manager of R-Ladies Global Twitter account (@RLadiesGlobal).

title: Campus useR Group Frankfurt: April meeting: Share your favourite thing about R or RStudio  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
There is a sheer endless amount of things to know about R and RStudio – and only this many things you will ever get to know. This holds especially true once you've found a workaround for doing something particular because you're little likely to search for more efficient ways of handling that matter. In our experience, the best way to learn the little things that make an impact is through other useRs.

For our April meetup, we would like to draw from the experiences of other useRs' and ask each of the participants to show their favorite thing about R or RStudio. Whether it's an underused feature, a package, a function or a shortcut you discovered - let us know! If it is a brand new feature of the latest version of R or RStudio – we're happy to hear about it!

There is no need to prepare a fancy presentation on something highly sophisticated. Just take a minute and think about the things that you really like and want others to know about. As always, R users of all levels of expertise are welcome. There is always something new to learn for everyone.

title: R-Ladies Santiago: Introducción a Tidymodels (parte 2): modelos mixtos  [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
Esta segunda parte del taller de introducción a Tidymodels estará a cargo de Alejandra Tapia Silva y estará dirigida a personas nuevas en el modelado con efectos mixtos. Cubrirá aspectos introductorios de este tema esperando que sea un punto de partida para el uso de estos modelos con R y {tidymodels}. No se utilizan fórmulas matemáticas, en un intento de hacerlo amigable e intuitivo y así poder dar atención a una audiencia más amplia.
Para aprovechar mejor este taller, es necesario tener algo de experiencia con análisis exploratorio de datos y modelos lineales, de tal manera de poder transitar sin mucho obstáculo teórico por cada una de las etapas del modelamiento con efectos mixtos. Además, es necesario contar con conocimientos iniciales de algunos paquetes del tidyverse (como {readr} y {dplyr}).

- REQUERIMIENTOS

Además de {tidyverse} y {tidymodels}, que utilizamos en la primera parte de este taller, es necesario instalar los siguientes paquetes:

> install.packages(c("broom.mixed","lme4","lmerTest"))

Luego del taller se dejarán referencias para quienes tengan interés en una explicación más detallada sobre modelos mixtos y {tidymodels}, de tal manera que cuando comiencen a usar estas herramientas con sus propios datos dispongan de mayor información. El material del taller quedará disponible en https://github.com/alejandraandrea/slides-xaringan-mixed-models

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA

Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
¡Te esperamos!

title: R-Ladies Bucharest: R-Ladies Bucharest #16: Julia Silge - Three reasons to choose Tidymodels  [Virtual] , Romania, Europe
description:
Join us for a new session on the 23rd of March, 7PM EET ! We continue our meetups with #goodRvibes and a speaker you'll definitely enjoy!

Three reasons to use tidymodels with Julia Silge

Modeling and machine learning in R involve a bewildering array of heterogeneous packages, and establishing good statistical practice is challenging in any language. The tidymodels (tidymodels.org) collection of packages offers a consistent, flexible framework for your modeling and machine learning work to address these problems. In this talk, we’ll focus on three specific reasons to consider using tidymodels. We will start with model characteristics themselves, move to the wise management of your data budget, and finish with feature engineering.

Julia Silge is a data scientist and software engineer at RStudio PBC where she works on open source modeling tools. She is an author, an international keynote speaker, and a real-world practitioner focusing on data analysis and machine learning practice. Julia loves text analysis, making beautiful charts, and communicating about technical topics with diverse audiences.

title: R-Ladies Columbus: R-Ladies Columbus Monthly Meetup  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
This month we will be hearing about a wide range of practical applications of R in the agronomy field!

Dr. Marin Harbur will be introduce her work with machine learning and Shiny applications. She will then provide an introduction to the use of spatial statistics in R. This will include map projections, the spatial features (sf) package, and kriging (interpolating) data using stars datasets. She will also show how to present spatial data using the leaflet package.

Marin is a Senior Data Analyst at Winfield United, the crop inputs division of Land O Lakes. She is also an Assistant Teaching Professor in the Department of Agronomy at Iowa State University, where she teaches Agronomy 513, Quantitative Methods in Agronomy. She graduated from Iowa State in 2003, where she co-majored in Crop Production and Physiology and Ecology and Evolutionary Biology. Marin lives in Lima Ohio with her wife, Kathleen, and two sons.

R-Ladies provides a harassment-free space to all who are interested to share and learn about R!*

Are you a woman or gender-non-conforming person interested in speaking? Please message the organizers!
___________________________________________________________________________________

We are holding our meetups remotely until further notice.

* R-Ladies Global Code of Conduct: https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

title: R-Ladies Twin Cities: Building and using lmeresampler for hierarchical linear models  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description: Jenna K. spent the summer of 2020 working on the R package lmeresampler (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/lmeresampler/index.html). During this meetup, Jenna will describe hierarchical linear models, the package's functions, the changes in package dependencies and parallelization that she implemented to streamline the code, and why she and her advisor chose to make those updates.

title: R-Ladies Riverside: A Semi-Tidy Tuesday:  Dataframe to simple maps  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Hello, RiveRside community ;-)

Come join us for a virtual meeting of networking and learning next Tuesday, April 13th, 12:00 PM (PST). Don't forget to RSVP in our Meetup to get access to the meeting's ID and password.

Whether you are new to R or a data scientist, join us for an introduction to Maps in R. We will introduce a variety of packages to use coordinates from a dataframe and create maps without GIS software.

At the end of the meeting, we will have time to help each other with any R-related questions.

Please have R and RStudio already installed on your computers.

Big thanks to UCR Library and UCR GradQuant for supporting us, and to our guest speaker *Tessa Shates* from the Department of Entomology at UCR!

See you soon!

ps: are you already following us at @RLadiesRiversd twitter?

title: R-Ladies Vienna: PyLadies and R-Ladies Vienna: Intro to Python, Austria, Europe
description:
We are proud to announce the collaboration of the PyLadies and R-Ladies Vienna groups for a series of events aimed at fostering the collaboration and synergies between our communities.

We invite you to join us for the first event of the series: Workshop on introduction to Python. Whether you are already proficient in R and want to gradually add Python to your portfolio or want to learn some programming basics in a faster pace and a form of a lecture, this tutorial will serve as a starting point for your journey.

The agenda of the workshop will be:
Intro to Python - syntax, loop, functions
Basic data types and structures
Reading data
Examples and use cases

To be able to follow the course and try things yourselves, we recommend to install Python (add to PATH if on Windows) and if you do not have a favorite code editor, we would suggest to install Atom or VSCode https://www.python.org/downloads/ https://atom.io/ https://code.visualstudio.com/ else feel free to use what you like.

Can't wait to meet you and share some love for Python!

Both events are preliminary steps to our final event: Panel Discussion about conjunction of both worlds with PyLadies and RLadies on board, which will take place on[masked].

You can follow @PyLadies_Vie (http://www.twitter.com/PyLadies_Vie) on Twitter.
If you want to join our Slack, send us echo on [masked]
We also have a facebook group to share ideas or questions: https://www.facebook.com/groups/2387073381541947/

title: R-Ladies Vienna: PyLadies & RLadies Vienna: Intro to R  [Virtual] , Austria, Europe
description:
We are proud to announce the collaboration of the PyLadies and R-Ladies Vienna meetup groups for a series of events aimed at fostering the collaboration and synergies between our communities.

We invite you to join us for the second event of the series: Introduction to R Workshop. Whether you are just starting out your data analytics journey and want to learn some programming basics or are a Python user who would like to add R to your skill set, this tutorial will serve as a starting point for your journey.

We are happy to welcome Camilla Damian as our trainer for this workshop, who will offer an interactive online tutorial where she will cover:

Brief intro to R as a programming language
Data structures and functions
Reading data into R
Basic data visualization in R
Examples and use cases

Camilla is a PhD Candidate in the field of Mathematics in Business and Economics and an experienced useR, who also has years of experience in teaching quantitative methods using R at an undergrad level.

We recommend you install R and RStudio before the start of the meetup (https://cran.r-project.org/ and https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/).

The first part of the series (Introduction to Python) held by PyLadies Vienna will take place on[masked] online. More information can be found here: https://meetu.ps/e/JSm1s/mTf66/a.

Both events are preliminary steps to our final event: Panel Discussion about conjunction of both worlds with PyLadies and RLadies on board, which will take place on[masked] at 16:00.

See you soon online!
Your R-Ladies Vienna Organizing Team

title: R-Ladies Vienna: PyLadies & R-Ladies Vienna: Panel discussion , Austria, Europe
description:
We invite you to join us for the third event of our joint series with PyLadies: Panel Discussion - R and Python with experts. Whether you are familiar with only R, Python, mastering both of them or just starting your journey now, we think this is the event for you. More info about topics and programme will be added very soon.

During the unique connection of both worlds, you shall hear about from our awesome panelists, who will try to answer all your possible questions:

Oliwia Lewandowska - Data Scientist at Looping Group, Berlin with a focus on Natural Language Processing & Data Storytelling. Experienced in R & SQL - passionate about mastering Python.

Jillian Augustine-:Jill is a data scientist in the Digital Excellence team at Mondi Group. Through her background in molecular biology as well as having worked in the telecommunications- and manufacturing industries, she has experience working on a diverse range of use cases using both R and Python.

Alexandra Avalos Pacheco - postdoctoral fellow in Statistics at Harvard Medical School in the Harvard-MIT Center for Regulatory Science (CRS) and part of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (DFCI) in the Department of Data Science.

Olivera Janic is a Quantitative Credit Risk Analyst at Raiffeisen Bank International. She has 7 years of experience in Market and Credit Risk Management. Her R journey started at WU during master studies in Quantitative Finance and continued at RBI where Python came along. Automatization, software engineering and diverse credit risk calculations are part of her daily routine.

Our Panel Discussion will be moderated by Kseniya Khamina, Scientist, PhD in Immunology, with experience in genetics and virology.

See you soon!
Your R-Ladies Vienna & PyLadies Vienna Organizers

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: {R-Ladies Toolbox Series} Part 4: Version Control  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
R-Ladies Toolbox Series - Essentials for women and minority genders in academia, science and data analysis presents:

--> Version Control by Christin Zasada (R-Ladies Global Team, R-Ladies Berlin) <--

Title: Make your first merge request

Talk description: Version control can be tempting at the beginning. Git and GitHub are a great resource of tools and code. Worldwide people are contributing to each other projects and driving R package development. In my talk I would like to introduce you to a simplified but effective strategy for shared code development. We'll walk through your first merge request using command line and Gitlabs browser interface. Make sure that you have your GitLab account ready.
Here is the link to the get started page with some useful information including how to set up an account:
https://docs.github.com/en/github/getting-started-with-github
Also here is a short video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f_XsJIHSLRg

Speaker Bio: At the end of her studies of biosystem engineering Christin decided to change from Excel to R for her diploma thesis. Since then she is using R in her daily research, first as a PhD student in basic cancer research in Berlin, nowadays as bioinformatics scientist in pharmaceutical company in Toulouse France. Right after her PhD she founded R-Ladies Berlin and supported the R-Ladies global team until last year. After some abstinence She is happy to be back in the community and is looking forward to meet up with you.

Calling all students, academics, and women in science! R-Ladies Freiburg presents a five-part guest series aimed at women and gender minorities in academia, science and data analysis, from first semester students to tenured researchers. Leading R-Ladies from around the world will lead us through the most fundamental steps to studying and working in academia, from analyzing results, to presenting them clearly, ensuring their reproducibility, and keeping track of all your changes. The series will close with a panel discussion from women around the world, who will speak about their experiences with science.

This series is funded by the “Pädagogische Hochschule Freiburg”, the University of Education in Freiburg.

Participants who take part in all five meetups can receive a certificate of participation.

Everyone is welcome to join and we hope for a warm exchange between students and researchers, as well as R-Ladies from the wider community.

title: AthensR: "Analysing Political Speeches in R: Some Approaches" with Evan Odell  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
Abstract: Legislative debate transcripts can provide unique insights into politics and policy. They can be used to identify popular topics among different legislators, reveal party factions that do not show up in voting behaviour, and longitudinal changes in the language used to discuss certain topics, amongst other things. In this webinar I'll discuss some approaches and potential pitfalls to analysing legislative debate, using the British House of Commons as an example.

Biography: Evan Odell is a junior data consultant at Pandata and R programmer, based in Berlin. Evan has written numerous R packages, primarily for accessing and processing data, and created a dataset of UK House of Commons speeches available as a single RDS or CSV file. He has previously worked for Disability Rights UK, Queen's University and as a freelancer for London Business School.

Sponsors: Jumping Rivers - datascience training and consultancy. (www.JumpingRivers.com)

title: AthensR: LondonR: Text Analysis in R workshop  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description: On Tuesday 23rd March at 5.30 pm LondonR will be hosting a free workshop. 'Text Analysis in R' will be taught by Hannah Alexander and supported by Elizabeth Brown. Please register here for a place, we look forward to seeing you there: https://ti.to/londonr/londonr-23-march-2021

title: AthensR: {ggplot2} Wizardry: My Favorite Tricks and Secrets for Beautiful Plots in R  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
In this talk, Cédric presents his favorite tips and tricks with regard to the {ggplot2} package, covering {ggplot2} functionality to improve the design of your graph as well as a collection of interesting extension packages. He is going to cover a diverse collection of tips so hopefully everyone, no matter if beginner or an experienced {ggplot2} user, will learn something helpful!

After the presentation, there will be a live-coding part where you can follow along Cédric in creating an beautiful graph. To follow along, please have the following packages installed:

install.packages(c("tidyverse", "systemfonts", "scico", "ggtext", "ggforce", "ggdist", "magick", "patchwork"))

Note: This is an extended version of the {ggplot2} talk that Cédric gave recently at the Outlier Conference.

[Bio]
Cédric is a computational ecologist by training and a data visualization designer by heart with more than 10 years of hypothesis-driven research experience. For all his projects, no matter if scientific, client or personal projects, he uses {ggplot2} to create powerful and aesthetically pleasing visualizations.

[About]
This event is organized by the Oslo useR! Group (https://www.meetup.com/Oslo-useR-Group/) and will be co-hosted by the Skåne useR! Group (https://www.meetup.com/Skane-R-User-Group/).

title: AthensR: Shiny in production with {golem} - Brighton R  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
We're delighted to host Chris Beeley, Senior Data Scientist at Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust, who will speak about the working practices that have evolved at Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust that are focused on allowing a group of data scientists to collaborate on Shiny applications, ensuring that the code that they write is robust, error free, and easily deployable. Shiny applications are produced according to best practice as defined by the {golem} package, and the modularity inherent in that approach is key to making the applications robust as well as allowing the git and GitHub based collaboration to work effectively.

A number of examples of modular and {golem} based development will be discussed, including some of technical hurdles and challenges faced by developers who are beginning to use Shiny modules, and some of the advanced features of Shiny and {golem} that can make building robust and scalable applications easier.

title: AthensR: Get Your Results Faster With {future} [useR! Oslo]  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
The {future} package offers a unifying framework to distributed computing in R. It lets you run exactly the same code – and achieve exactly the same results – sequentially on your laptop, in parallel on your laptop, in the cloud, or on large computing clusters. In this talk, Øystein will highlight various ways {future} lets you do your data science tasks more efficiently, from file system operations and preparation of large datasets to statistics and machine learning tasks like cross-validation, bootstrapping, and simulations. He'll focus particularly on functional programming with {future.apply} and {furrr} in parallel on a decent laptop, but will also touch upon cloud and cluster computing and package development.

[Bio]
Øystein Sørensen is an Associate Professor in Statistics at the Department of Psychology, University of Oslo (UiO). He works on both applied data analysis projects within cognitive neuroscience as well as development of new statistical tools, typically involving generalized additive models, and he is the author of four R packages. He received his PhD from the UiO in 2014, after which he worked as a data scientist in Storebrand and NextBridge analytics prior to joining UiO in 2018. His homepage is https://osorensen.rbind.io/.

title: AthensR: My Journey To Transparency And Reproducibility [R Lille]   [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
In this talk, I (Mickaël Canouil, https://m.canouil.fr) will chronicle my journey towards a more transparent and reproducible work environment. I will talk about the changes and improvements that I have implemented in my team, detailing the transition of infrastructure used when I arrived to an infrastructure using Docker and and the {renv} R package.

[Bio]
I am a biostatistician (Ph.D.) and the head of a small team within a research laboratory, working primarily on the genetics of diabetes and obesity.
I have developed a few R packages, and although some are not very useful, they are most definitely entertaining (i.e., https://github.com/mcanouil/ggpacman/).
I also enjoy watching movies and playing with R (https://m.canouil.fr/imdb_ratings/).

[About]
This event (in English) is organised by the R Lille user group (Lille, France).

title: R-Ladies Valparaíso: Introducción a Tidymodels (parte 2): modelos mixtos  [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
Esta segunda parte del taller de introducción a Tidymodels estará a cargo de Alejandra Tapia Silva y estará dirigida a personas nuevas en el modelado con efectos mixtos. Cubrirá aspectos introductorios de este tema esperando que sea un punto de partida para el uso de estos modelos con R y {tidymodels}. No se utilizan fórmulas matemáticas, en un intento de hacerlo amigable e intuitivo y así poder dar atención a una audiencia más amplia.
Para aprovechar mejor este taller, es necesario tener algo de experiencia con análisis exploratorio de datos y modelos lineales, de tal manera de poder transitar sin mucho obstáculo teórico por cada una de las etapas del modelamiento con efectos mixtos. Además, es necesario contar con conocimientos iniciales de algunos paquetes del tidyverse (como {readr} y {dplyr}).

- REQUERIMIENTOS

Además de {tidyverse} y {tidymodels}, que utilizamos en la primera parte de este taller, es necesario instalar los siguientes paquetes:

> install.packages(c("broom.mixed","lme4","lmerTest"))

Luego del taller se dejarán referencias para quienes tengan interés en una explicación más detallada sobre modelos mixtos y {tidymodels}, de tal manera que cuando comiencen a usar estas herramientas con sus propios datos dispongan de mayor información. El material del taller quedará disponible en https://github.com/alejandraandrea/slides-xaringan-mixed-models

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA

Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
¡Te esperamos!

title: R-Ladies Valparaíso: Manejo de tablas con {dplyr}  [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
Si ya tienes un manejo básico de R y {dplyr}, y quieres comenzar a trabajar uniendo tablas de datos, este taller es para ti. Repasaremos las principales funciones de dplyr y utilizaremos inner_join, left_join, full-join y otras más para el manejo de tablas. Esta sesión estará a cargo de Javiera Riffo (https://twitter.com/JavieraRiffoTo1), Analista de Inteligencia de Negocios y Magíster en Ciencias de la Ingeniería.

- REQUERIMIENTOS
Antes del taller es necesario que instales es paquete {tidyverse}:
> install.packages("tidyverse")
El conjunto de datos con el que trabajaremos se encuentra en: www.kaggle.com/rtatman/lego-database.
Hemos preparado un proyecto en RStudio Cloud, que incluye los datos a utilizar y los paquetes necesarios: proyecto en donde trabajarás, a partir del siguiente link: https://rstudio.cloud/project/2432177.

Este evento se realizará a través de la plataforma Zoom. Unos minutos antes de la reunión compartiremos la clave de acceso.

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA
Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish

¡Te esperamos!

title: R-Ladies East Lansing: R-package development  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
“Develop an R package”, they said… What does this even mean?

In this session with a live demo, we shall demystify the creation of an R package. R packages are mostly well-organized folders, and there are automatic tools to help. Let’s dive into the wonders of usethis! We shall also see why to create a package (or not). We shall furthermore explain how to improve your R package and your own package development skills. And how to solve the specific new challenges you will encounter! Last but not least we will discuss how to find your happy place in the world of R package development.

Do you want to be more of a devoted maintainer of one single package? Or perhaps a valued contributor to dozens of packages?

==================
About the Speaker
==================
Maelle Salmon is a R(esearch) Software Engineer & Blogger based in Nancy, France. She is also the associate editor for rOpenSci’s Software Peer Review (peer-review system of R packages), and the main manager of R-Ladies Global Twitter account (@RLadiesGlobal).
https://masalmon.eu

title: R-Ladies Amsterdam: [ONLINE]- Introduction to Tidyverse  [Virtual] , Netherlands, Europe
description:
Hi, everybody!
We hope that you and your family are doing well. We are super excited to have Nutsa Nanuashvili, a data enthusiast that recently graduated in Cognitive Sciences to introduce you to the tidyverse universe!

DESCRIPTION
-------------------
The goal of this workshop is to get familiar with some useful and easy to use data transformation techniques in R. For this, we are going to go through some handy functions and commands from the famous tidyverse ecosystem. Hopefully with these tricks and tips you’re going to get more confident around transforming & organizing data.
During the meeting we will discuss some concepts and provide code examples, after which we’ll go through exercises to try out the newly learned concepts by ourselves. Some of the topics we’ll cover are, tidy data concept, reshaping datasets, what is and how to use the pipe %>% operator, and manipulating data columns and rows.
For all these we're going to use the dataset about penguins from palmerpenguins package.

PROGRAMME
----------------------
18.30- 18.45 Virtual Welcome
18.45- 20.30 Workshop and Q&A

ABOUT NUTSA
-------------------
I recently graduated with a master’s degree in Cognitive Neuroscience from the University of Amsterdam, Institute of Interdisciplinary Studies. I love programming and working on data. I especially love coding in R and I used it a lot while doing my master's projects. While looking for new adventures, I enjoy working on data and learning new concepts as part of my side-projects.

PREREQUISITES
-----------------------
A basic knowledge of R is recommended. Please install the tidyverse package.

CODE OF CONDUCT
----------------------------
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn.

title: R-Ladies Baltimore: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Building websites in RStudio (Virtual)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is the local Baltimore chapter for the larger R-Ladies global organization (rladies.org) to promote gender diversity in the R community.

The next event is Thursday April 1, 2021 from 3-4:30pm (virtual meetup on Zoom). We will have an exciting presentation from Maria Tackett (https://www.mariatackett.net) an Assistant Professor of the Practice in the Department of Statistical Science at Duke University! She will give a talk on how to build websites using RStudio! If you've ever thought about making a website for yourself or your project, you won't want to miss this wonderful presentation!

WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R & want to learn about an incredibly powerful package!
- If you need to make a website, and want to learn how to do it in R!
- If you have a website, and want to learn how to convert it to a website in R!

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

AGENDA

FAQ:
Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. However, we ask that cis men come as guests of women and gender minorities to our events to promote a sense support and encouragement for women and gender minorities in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies. Please also take the time to review our code of conduct before you attend: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

The term "women and gender minorities" is inclusive of individuals who identify as female (trans and cis), trans-men, non-binary, genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, intersex, and all minority genders).

Important to know:
- If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Books In Bars - Data Feminism  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Spend Friday night discussing Data Feminism (https://www.bookdepository.com/Data-Feminism-Catherine-DIgnazio/9780262044004).

A new way of thinking about data science and data ethics that is informed by the ideas of intersectional feminism.

Today, data science is a form of power. It has been used to expose injustice, improve health outcomes, and topple governments. But it has also been used to discriminate, police, and surveil. This potential for good, on the one hand, and harm, on the other, makes it essential to ask: Data science by whom? Data science for whom? Data science with whose interests in mind? The narratives around big data and data science are overwhelmingly white, male, and techno-heroic. In Data Feminism, Catherine D'Ignazio and Lauren Klein present a new way of thinking about data science and data ethics—one that is informed by intersectional feminist thought.

Illustrating data feminism in action, D'Ignazio and Klein show how challenges to the male/female binary can help challenge other hierarchical (and empirically wrong) classification systems. They explain how, for example, an understanding of emotion can expand our ideas about effective data visualization, and how the concept of invisible labor can expose the significant human efforts required by our automated systems. And they show why the data never, ever “speak for themselves.”

Data Feminism offers strategies for data scientists seeking to learn how feminism can help them work toward justice, and for feminists who want to focus their efforts on the growing field of data science. But Data Feminism is about much more than gender. It is about power, about who has it and who doesn't, and about how those differentials of power can be challenged and changed..

PS This book is available free online: https://data-feminism.mitpress.mit.edu/

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Studying mental health and evaluating policies during the COVID-19 pandemic  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
We are very excited to welcome Dr. Elizabeth Stuart, an internationally renowned expert in statistics, education, and mental health!

Elizabeth A. Stuart, Ph.D. is Bloomberg Professor of American Health in the Department of Mental Health at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, with joint appointments in the Department of Biostatistics and the Department of Health Policy and Management. She received her Ph.D. in statistics in 2004 from Harvard University and is a Fellow of the American Statistical Association (ASA) and the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS). Prior to her time at JHSPH she was a Researcher at Mathematica Policy Research. Dr. Stuart has extensive experience in methods for estimating causal effects and dealing with the complications of missing data in experimental and non-experimental studies, particularly as applied to mental health, public policy, and education. Her primary research interests include designs for estimating causal effects in non-experimental settings (such as propensity scores), and methods to assess and enhance the generalizability of randomized trials to target populations, and she teaches courses and short courses on these topics. She has received research funding for her work from the National Science Foundation, the Institute of Education Sciences, the WT Grant Foundation, and the National Institutes of Health and has served on advisory panels for the National Academy of Sciences, the US Department of Education, and the Patient Centered Outcomes Research Institute.

"Analysing Political Speeches in R: Some Approaches"

Abstract: Legislative debate transcripts can provide unique insights into politics and policy. They can be used to identify popular topics among different legislators, reveal party factions that do not show up in voting behaviour, and longitudinal changes in the language used to discuss certain topics, amongst other things. In this webinar I'll discuss some approaches and potential pitfalls to analysing legislative debate, using the British House of Commons as an example.

Biography: Evan Odell is a junior data consultant at Pandata and R programmer, based in Berlin. Evan has written numerous R packages, primarily for accessing and processing data, and created a dataset of UK House of Commons speeches available as a single RDS or CSV file. He has previously worked for Disability Rights UK, Queen's University and as a freelancer for London Business School.

title: Bogotá R Users Group: Fractales y Wikipedia   [Virtual] , Colombia, Latin America
description:
*ESTA SESIÓN NO ES PROPIAMENTE DE R PERO PUEDE SER DE INTERÉS PARA LOS USUARIOS DE ESTE GRUPO*

¿Qué es un fractal? ¿Qué es un articulo de Wikipedia? ¿Qué vemos cuando decimos fractal o Wikipedia?

No es un secreto que en nuestra experiencia cotidiana aparezca Wikipedia para resolver una duda, hacer una apuesta o revisar una idea. Una obra de arte, un monumento o un país lejano que queremos visitar, casi siempre, están en Wikipedia. Pero ¿Un fractal? ¿Qué es un fractal?
Parece que no es tan cotidiano como Wikipedia. Y ¿Qué tal si buscamos un fractal en Wikipedia?

En esta ocasión vamos a performar un fractal, y para ello, usaremos a Wikipedia como portal, y de paso, la sacaremos del portátil y del celular hacia mundo físico tridimensional. “Fractalizaremos” Wikipedia para vivir la experiencia de la cotidianidad: de los datos digitales a los datos corporales. Dimensiones sensoriales: afectivas, hápticas y perceptivas.

Materiales

Wikipedia en un dispositivo (portátil o celular)
Tizas de colores
Un metro de costurera
Reglas de madera o tablas rectas de 50 cm

Imparte John Barragán:

Bogotano amante de la ciencia ciudadana, la escuela y la Wikipedia. Ha ha trabajado como profesor de física, escritor de secuencias de aprendizaje y geofísico. Activista de los datos abiertos se caracteriza por intentar abrir la escuela para cambiar el mundo a través de prototipos colaborativos. Estudiante de doctorado en filosofía y fanático de los libros.

title: R-Ladies RTP: Navigating RStudio & R Basics  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
By the end of this event, participants will be able to describe the main components of RStudio (e.g., console, script editor, etc.). They will also be able to explain basic R syntax (e.g, "(" versus "["), data types (e.g., character versus integer), and programming concepts (e.g., functions versus packages). We will use live coding demonstrations and participates will actively engage with the instructor throughout the workshop.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them (i.e., attend through the "guest" function on their host's RSVP, not as a separate RSVP). This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

Agenda:
• 6:30pm - 6:45pm - Introductions
• 6:45pm - 7:00pm - Navigating RStudio
• 7:00pm - 8:00pm - R Basics
• 8:00pm - 8:20pm - Practice
• 8:20m - 8:30pm - Wrap up

Who is this for?
This meetup is for beginners who have **no experience** programming in R (or another coding language). We will use live coding demonstrations and participates will actively engage with the instructor throughout the workshop.

**Before you join**, please install the most recent version of R **as well as** RStudio on your computer before attending this meetup event. Here are links to free downloads for R (https://cran.r-project.org/) and RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download). Downloading and installing both of these programs before this meetup will help us keep to our schedule and make sure you learn the most you can while at the meetup event.

If you have trouble installing the software, please contact Sheila at [masked] at least 48 hours **before the event** so we can find a time to meet and work through software installation issues.

What should I bring?
Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the capabilities to run R **and** RStudio. See information above about how to install R **and** RStudio.

Where will it take place?
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.
